events.title: The Medieval Inquisition
events.description: The Church established the Inquisition to root out heresy, creating a system of investigation, trial, and punishment that became infamous for cruelty and became a symbol of religious intolerance.
events.details: As heresies spread (Catharism, Waldensians, Lollards), the Church sought to combat them. In 1184 AD, Pope Lucius III established procedures for investigating heresy. In 1233 AD, Pope Gregory IX formalized the Medieval Inquisition as an official papal institution. Inquisitors were judges appointed to investigate suspected heretics, question them, and punish those found guilty. The Inquisition developed procedures: accused heretics were questioned (sometimes under torture), allowed to confess and recant, or punished. Punishments ranged from public penance to imprisonment to execution (usually burning). The Inquisition kept records that reveal its operations - in one Spanish inquisition over 40 years, thousands were tried and hundreds executed. Henry Kamen notes that the Medieval Inquisition was actually more lenient than later Spanish Inquisition: many heretics were given opportunity to recant and receive absolution. Yet the Inquisition's system of suspicion, secret witnesses, torture, and execution was terrifying. People accused of heresy lost civil rights, faced torture, and had no guarantee of justice. The Inquisition often targeted marginalized groups: Jews, Muslims, poor heretics, women. It raised fundamental questions about religious authority and coercion: Does the Church have right to kill heretics? Can God's truth be protected through violence? Medieval church leaders generally believed yes - if heresy threatened souls' salvation, suppressing it was spiritual mercy. Yet the Inquisition's brutality troubled even medieval observers. When the Spanish Inquisition emerged in 1478 AD, it became even more systematic and notorious. The Medieval Inquisition set precedent for religious institutions using violence to enforce orthodoxy.

events.title: Francis of Assisi and Mendicant Orders
events.description: Francis founded the Franciscan order, emphasizing radical poverty and spiritual simplicity, creating mendicant (begging) orders that revitalized Christian devotion.
events.details: Francis of Assisi (1181-1226) was son of a wealthy merchant who rejected wealth and status to follow Jesus in radical simplicity. Around 1209 AD, Francis felt called to rebuild the Church - literally at first, then spiritually. He took vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, living as a beggar. His devotion was infectious. Others joined him, and by 1210 AD, Pope Innocent III approved the Franciscan order. Franciscans took vows of absolute poverty - they owned nothing individually or communally. They survived by begging and manual labor. This radical approach appealed to people tired of wealthy, worldly clergy. Francis wrote: "No possession you must own, no wealth of this world grasp" (Testament of Francis). Francis also emphasized love for creation - his sermon to birds and his care for animals reflected a spiritual vision of interconnected creation. He also pioneered stigmatism - receiving visible wounds matching Christ's crucifixion. His biography by Bonaventure describes stigmata appearing on Francis's body - a controversial claim that some skeptics rejected. Dominicans (Order of Preachers) founded by Dominic de Guzman developed similarly, emphasizing preaching and education while also taking mendicant vows. Mendicant orders represented spiritual renewal: they challenged wealthy monasteries' worldliness by embodying Gospel poverty. Ironically, as mendicant orders gained followers, some accumulated property and wealth - repeating the pattern they critiqued. Yet Franciscans and Dominicans remained influential, producing many theologians (Thomas Aquinas was Dominican; Duns Scotus was Franciscan) and missionaries. Francis's emphasis on God's love, creation's value, and spiritual simplicity influenced Christianity significantly. His mystical approach offered alternative to scholasticism's intellectual emphasis.

events.title: Papal Power at Its Peak: Pope Innocent III
events.description: Pope Innocent III wielded unprecedented power, placing kingdoms under interdict, excommunicating kings, and establishing papal supremacy over temporal rulers.
events.details: Innocent III (1160-1216) became pope at 37 and immediately asserted bold papal authority. He believed the Pope held ultimate authority over all Christendom - both spiritual and temporal matters. He wrote: "As the moon derives its light from the sun... so the royal power derives its dignity from the papal authority" (Sermon on Consecration). Innocent III placed entire kingdoms under interdict (suspending sacraments and worship) when kings defied papal authority. He excommunicated King John of England for disputes over church appointment, then lifted the ban when John submitted. He pressured King Philip Augustus of France on marital matters. He even organized the Fourth Crusade against heretical Cathars (though it went terribly wrong, sacking Constantinople instead). Innocent established the College of Cardinals' role in papal elections, standardizing papal succession. He convened the Fourth Lateran Council (1215) which made major church decisions on doctrine, clergy discipline, and lay practice. Innocent III was undoubtedly brilliant - he reformed Church administration, increased papal revenues, and expanded papal diplomatic power. Yet his aggressive use of excommunication and interdict raised questions: Could spiritual weapons be used as political tools? When entire nations lost sacraments because of political disputes, did that serve Christianity? Thomas Head notes that Innocent III represented papal monarchy at its zenith - the Pope as ultimate Christian authority. Yet his example also showed the dangers of mixing spiritual and temporal power. Later popes who lacked his political skill faced challenges, and papal authority gradually declined. By the Reformation, papal power's overreach had generated significant backlash.

events.title: Black Death: Plague and Church Crisis
events.description: The bubonic plague killed one-third of Europe's population, devastating the Church's credibility and forcing theological and social reckoning.
events.details: Beginning in 1347 AD, the bubonic plague swept across Europe, killing approximately 75-200 million people - roughly one-third of Europe's population. Entire villages were wiped out. The death toll was catastrophic and seemed endless. Medieval people had no understanding of germ transmission; they attributed plague to divine punishment, astrological causes, or Jewish conspiracy (leading to terrible pogroms). The Church faced a credibility crisis. If God were truly guiding the Church, why couldn't priests stop the plague? Why did priests and monks die at similar rates to ordinary people? The Church's elaborate theological system seemed powerless before plague's indiscriminate killing. Some priests performed masses in protective gear rather than ministering to sick (Boccaccio's Decameron describes this). Others were heroic - many clergy died ministering to plague victims. The plague also created social upheaval: labor shortages led peasants to demand higher wages, challenging feudal hierarchy. Some flagellant movements emerged - people whipping themselves believing pain might appease God's wrath. Others questioned Church authority entirely. The Black Death didn't immediately destroy Church power, but it weakened institutional confidence. Philip Ziegler notes that the plague exposed Church's limitations and sparked questioning that would contribute to later Reformation challenges. It also sparked mysticism - since institutional religion seemed powerless, people sought direct experience of God. Ockham's theology emphasizing God's absolute power gained influence - if God allowed plague despite Church's prayers, then God's will transcended human institutions. The Black Death thus represented a turning point: medieval Christendom's confidence was shaken, opening space for religious questioning and reform.

events.title: Avignon Papacy: Popes Depart Rome
events.description: Popes relocated to Avignon in southern France, corrupting papal independence and demonstrating the dangers of temporal entanglement.
events.details: In 1309 AD, Pope Clement V moved the papal residence from Rome to Avignon in France, ostensibly for safety during political turmoil. The move was meant to be temporary. Yet popes remained in Avignon for 68 years - seven consecutive popes stayed there. The relocation had serious consequences. Popes became dependent on French kings for protection, compromising papal independence. Italian cardinals complained that Avignon was too far from Rome (the traditional seat of Peter). The Avignon papacy became associated with luxury and corruption - popes lived in grand palaces while charging high fees for church services. Simony (selling church offices) and nepotism (appointing relatives to high positions) flourished. Critics like Petrarch attacked the "Avignon captivity" (comparing it to Israel's Babylonian captivity). In 1377 AD, Pope Gregory XI finally returned to Rome, reestablishing the papal residence there. However, his death shortly after triggered the Western Schism (1378-1417) - multiple popes claimed legitimacy, each backed by different European powers, scandalizing the Church. The schism wasn't resolved until the Council of Constance (1414-1418) unified behind one pope. F. D. Logan notes that the Avignon period and Western Schism exposed papal governance's dysfunction. When the Pope fled Rome and multiple popes competed for authority, it became clear institutional Christianity needed reform. These crises contributed to demands for church reform that would explode with Martin Luther's Reformation in 1517.

events.title: John Wycliffe: Pre-Reformation Heretic
events.description: Wycliffe challenged papal authority and clerical corruption, arguing for Bible translation and church reform, prefiguring the Protestant Reformation by 150 years.
events.details: John Wycliffe (1320-1384) was an Oxford theologian who became increasingly critical of papal authority and church corruption. He argued that Scripture, not the Pope, held ultimate authority. He wrote that popes could be wrong: "The Pope can err, for he is but a man" (Wycliffe, On the Church). Wycliffe challenged the concept of papal indulgences (payments for forgiveness) and questioned transubstantiation (the doctrine that bread and wine become Christ's body and blood in the Eucharist). Most radically, Wycliffe insisted the Bible should be translated into English so ordinary people could read Scripture directly rather than depending on priests' interpretations. He led a translation project, producing the first complete English Bible (Wycliffe Bible, c. 1382). Wycliffe's followers, called Lollards, spread his teachings. They emphasized biblical authority, criticized papal corruption, and advocated clergy reform. Church authorities condemned Wycliffe's teachings in 1377. Though Wycliffe was protected by patrons and died naturally, his followers faced persecution - some were executed. The Council of Constance (1415) posthumously condemned Wycliffe, ordering his bones exhumed and burned. Yet Wycliffe's ideas persisted. Jan Hus, a Czech reformer influenced by Wycliffe, faced martyrdom in 1415, saying on the pyre that someday a white swan (Hus means goose) would come - arguably predicting Luther. Wycliffe thus represents pre-Reformation reform: he challenged papal authority, emphasized Scripture, and advocated church reform over a century before Luther. His example inspired later reformers and showed that challenges to papal authority predated the Reformation.

figures.name: Thomas Aquinas
figures.biography: Thomas Aquinas is the greatest medieval theologian and one of Christianity's most influential thinkers. Born in Italy to a noble family, Thomas joined the Dominican order despite his family's opposition. He studied under Albert the Great at Paris and Cologne, becoming a master theologian. Thomas taught at universities in Paris, Rome, and Naples. His masterwork is the Summa Theologiae (Summary of Theology) - a massive systematic theology covering hundreds of questions about God, creation, human nature, virtue, and salvation. Thomas argued that faith and reason work together - they don't conflict. He used Aristotle's philosophy to explain Christian doctrine, integrating classical learning with theology. Thomas developed the "Five Ways" - logical arguments for God's existence still studied today. He also wrote biblical commentaries, theological treatises, and mystical writings. Thomas's theology shaped Catholicism for centuries - his works became official Catholic doctrine. In 1567 AD, Pope Pius V declared Thomas a Doctor of the Church (highest theological honor). His integration of philosophy and theology influenced how Christianity engaged intellectual thought. Thomas also emphasized natural law - the idea that reason can discover moral truths written into creation, independent of Scripture. This had profound implications for ethics and law. Thomas was canonized in 1323, recognized as a saint. Yet interestingly, some of his teachings were condemned by bishops shortly after his death - medieval theologians didn't always agree with his conclusions. Still, Thomas became medieval theology's greatest figure.
figures.significance: Thomas Aquinas created the most comprehensive and influential medieval theological system. His thought shaped Catholic theology for 700+ years and demonstrated how faith and reason could work together.

figures.name: Bernard of Clairvaux
figures.biography: Bernard of Clairvaux was one of medieval Christianity's most influential figures. He founded the Cistercian monastery at Clairvaux and led the Cistercian reform movement. Bernard was known for mystical spirituality - he described the soul's union with God in intimate, even sensual language. His writings on divine love influenced medieval spirituality profoundly. Bernard was also a powerful political figure - popes consulted him on matters of church governance. He preached the Second Crusade in 1147 AD (though it proved disastrous). He debated heretics and defended orthodox theology. Bernard combined mystical experience with active engagement in church affairs. He wrote: "One should first be filled with the sweetness of love, and then poured out for the salvation of others" (Bernard, On Consideration). Bernard emphasized that love of God surpasses intellectual knowledge. This mystical emphasis offered alternative to developing scholasticism's intellectual focus. Bernard was known for extreme asceticism - harsh fasting, cold, physical discipline. He had a commanding presence and was a brilliant writer and speaker. Bernard's combination of mysticism, spirituality, and political engagement made him model medieval churchman. He was canonized in 1174, declared Doctor of the Church in 1830.
figures.significance: Bernard of Clairvaux influenced medieval spirituality through mystical theology emphasizing divine love. He demonstrated how spiritual devotion and political engagement could coexist.

figures.name: Francis of Assisi
figures.biography: Francis of Assisi is one of Christianity's most beloved saints. Born to wealth in Assisi, Italy, Francis initially pursued worldly ambitions and even military service. But in his mid-twenties, Francis experienced a spiritual awakening. He renounced his wealth and committed himself to radical poverty and spiritual simplicity. Francis believed following Jesus meant literal poverty - owning nothing, depending on begging and charity. He founded the Franciscan order emphasizing absolute poverty, simplicity, and spiritual devotion. Francis wrote the Canticle of the Sun, a beautiful poem celebrating God's creation - birds, water, fire, even death. He preached to birds and animals, treating all creation as expressing God's glory. Tradition says Francis received the stigmata - visible wounds matching Christ's crucifixion - which he kept hidden until after his death. Francis traveled extensively, even attempting to meet the Muslim Sultan during the Crusades, seeking peace. Francis combined deep spirituality with practical service. He worked with lepers and the poor personally. His spirituality was warm, personal, and accessible - emphasizing God's love and creation's beauty rather than abstract theology. Francis inspired thousands. His order grew rapidly despite strict poverty rules. Francis was canonized quickly after his death, and remains one of the most popular saints today. In recent centuries, his emphasis on creation and ecology has made him patron saint of animals and environment. Francis demonstrated Christianity's mystical tradition - direct experience of God's love, service to the poor, appreciation of creation - offering alternative to ecclesiastical hierarchy and scholastic theology.
figures.significance: Francis of Assisi represents medieval Christianity's mystical and devotional dimension. His emphasis on poverty, simplicity, and God's love influenced spirituality for centuries.

figures.name: Pope Innocent III
figures.biography: Innocent III was the most powerful pope of the medieval period. Elected at 37, he immediately asserted unprecedented papal authority. Innocent believed the Pope held ultimate authority over all Christendom - both spiritual and temporal. He placed entire kingdoms under interdict (suspension of sacraments) when kings defied papal authority. He excommunicated King John of England for church appointment disputes, forcing John to submit. He pressured King Philip of France on personal matters. Innocent organized the Fourth Crusade, though it went terribly wrong, sacking Constantinople. Innocent also reformed church administration, increased papal revenues, and expanded papal diplomatic power. He convened the Fourth Lateran Council (1215), which made major decisions on doctrine and church practice. Innocent III was brilliant and powerful, but his aggressive use of excommunication and interdict raised questions: Could spiritual weapons be political tools? When entire nations lost sacraments because of political disputes, did that serve Christianity? Innocent III represented papal monarchy at its peak - the Pope as ultimate Christian authority. Yet his example also showed dangers of mixing spiritual and temporal power.

figures.name: Jan Hus (John Hus)
figures.biography: Jan Hus was a Czech reformer and precursor to the Protestant Reformation. He was influenced by John Wycliffe's writings and adopted Wycliffe's emphasis on biblical authority and church reform. Hus was a popular preacher who advocated that ordinary people receive communion in both forms (bread and wine) rather than just bread as Rome required. He criticized clerical corruption and argued the Church should return to biblical simplicity. Church authorities saw Hus as dangerous. He was summoned to the Council of Constance in 1414, promised safe passage by the Holy Roman Emperor. However, church leaders broke that promise, tried Hus for heresy, and burned him at the stake on July 6, 1415. As flames consumed him, Hus reportedly sang hymns. According to some sources, he said someday a white swan (Hus means goose in Czech) would come - possibly predicting Martin Luther. Hus's death made him a martyr. His followers, the Hussites, revolted against papal authority and continued his reform movement. Hussite Wars lasted decades in Bohemia. Hus thus represents the bridge between medieval reform attempts (Wycliffe) and the Protestant Reformation (Luther). His martyrdom inspired later reformers. Though he died 102 years before Luther's Reformation, Hus prefigured its themes: biblical authority, church reform, clerical corruption critique, lay participation.

events.title: Martin Luther Posts the Ninety-Five Theses
events.description: Luther challenges the sale of indulgences, igniting widespread debate that catalyzes the Protestant Reformation.
events.details: On October 31, 1517, Martin Luther, an Augustinian monk and professor, reportedly posted his Ninety-Five Theses on the door of the Castle Church in Wittenberg, questioning the theology and practice of indulgences. He argued that forgiveness was God's gift through Christ, not a commodity to be purchased. The Theses quickly spread due to the printing press, turning a local disputation into a continental controversy. Luther's central claim—justification by faith alone—reoriented Christian theology toward reliance on Scripture and grace rather than ecclesiastical mediation. Philip Schaff notes that whether or not the literal nailing occurred, the publication of the Theses decisively launched the Reformation as a public movement.
significance: Catalyzed debate on indulgences and authority
Elevated Scripture and faith over ecclesiastical commerce
Marked the practical beginning of the Protestant Reformation
sources: Martin Luther, Ninety-Five Theses (1517)
Philip Schaff, History of the Christian Church Vol. 7
Justo Gonzalez, The Story of Christianity Vol. 2

events.title: Diet of Worms and Luther's Stand
events.description: Summoned before imperial authorities, Luther refuses to recant, asserting conscience bound to God's Word.
events.details: In April 1521, Luther appeared before Emperor Charles V and church officials at the Diet of Worms. Asked to recant his writings, Luther replied, "Unless I am convinced by the testimony of the Scriptures or by clear reason... my conscience is captive to the Word of God... Here I stand, I can do no other." He was declared an outlaw by the Edict of Worms. Frederick the Wise hid Luther at Wartburg Castle, where he translated the New Testament into German. The event dramatized the authority of Scripture over church decrees and elevated the role of vernacular Scripture in Christian life.
significance: Asserted Scripture's supremacy over ecclesiastical authority
Produced vernacular Bible shaping German language and piety
Hardened the split between reformers and Rome
sources: Edict of Worms (1521)
Roland Bainton, Here I Stand
Martin Luther, Address at Worms

events.title: Marburg Colloquy: Luther and Zwingli Dispute the Eucharist
events.description: German and Swiss reformers fail to unite over the Lord's Supper, revealing theological diversity within Protestantism.
events.details: Landgrave Philip of Hesse convened Luther and Huldrych Zwingli to forge unity among reformers. They agreed on fourteen articles but split over the fifteenth: Christ's presence in the Eucharist. Luther insisted "This is my body" meant a real presence (sacramental union), while Zwingli argued for a symbolic memorial. Their failure prevented a single Protestant front and foreshadowed enduring denominational differences.
significance: Demonstrated Protestant diversity on sacramental theology
Prevented political-military unity among reformers
Shaped trajectories of Lutheran and Reformed traditions
sources: Marburg Articles (1529)
Diarmiad MacCulloch, The Reformation
Justo Gonzalez, The Story of Christianity Vol. 2

events.title: Act of Supremacy Establishes English Reformation
events.description: Parliament recognizes Henry VIII as Supreme Head of the Church of England, severing papal authority.
events.details: Following disputes over his annulment, Henry VIII rejected papal jurisdiction. The 1534 Act of Supremacy declared the king head of the Church of England. Thomas Cranmer, Archbishop of Canterbury, steered reforms: the Book of Common Prayer (1549/1552), English liturgy, and doctrinal shifts. The settlement ebbed and flowed under subsequent monarchs, but the break with Rome was decisive.
significance: Ended papal authority in England
Established national church under the crown
Introduced English liturgy and reforming theology
sources: Act of Supremacy (1534)
Diarmaid MacCulloch, Thomas Cranmer
Eamon Duffy, The Stripping of the Altars

events.title: John Calvin's Geneva and the Institutes
events.description: Calvin systematizes Reformed theology in the Institutes and establishes disciplined church governance in Geneva.
events.details: Calvin published the first edition of the Institutes of the Christian Religion in 1536, expanding it repeatedly. Invited to Geneva, he implemented ecclesiastical ordinances (1541) structuring pastors, teachers, elders, and deacons, with consistorial discipline. Geneva became a center for training pastors and printing Reformed literature, spreading ideas across Europe.
significance: Systematized Reformed theology
Modeled disciplined church polity
Made Geneva a hub for Protestant mission and publishing
sources: John Calvin, Institutes of the Christian Religion
Ecclesiastical Ordinances of Geneva (1541)
Alister McGrath, Reformation Thought

events.title: Council of Trent and the Catholic Reformation
events.description: Catholic bishops reform discipline and clarify doctrine in response to Protestant challenges.
events.details: The Council of Trent met intermittently for 18 years, issuing decrees on Scripture and tradition, justification, the sacraments, and clerical discipline. It reaffirmed transubstantiation, the seven sacraments, and the necessity of grace and cooperation. Seminaries were mandated; abuses such as pluralism and absenteeism were curbed. The Jesuit order, founded by Ignatius of Loyola (1540), spearheaded Catholic renewal in education and mission.
significance: Clarified Catholic doctrine
Reformed clerical education and discipline
Launched global Catholic missions and renewal
sources: Decrees of the Council of Trent
John W. O’Malley, Trent: What Happened at the Council
Justo Gonzalez, The Story of Christianity Vol. 2

events.title: Peace of Augsburg Establishes Cuius Regio, Eius Religio
events.description: Princes choose Lutheran or Catholic confession for their territories, institutionalizing religious division.
events.details: After decades of conflict, the Peace of Augsburg allowed each imperial prince to determine his territory's religion (Lutheran or Catholic). Subjects could emigrate if they dissented. The settlement stabilized parts of Germany but entrenched confessional boundaries and excluded Reformed and Anabaptist groups, sowing seeds for future conflicts.
significance: Legalized Lutheran territories
Linked sovereignty to confessional choice
Excluded Reformed and radicals
sources: Peace of Augsburg (1555)
Heinz Schilling, Early Modern European Civilization
MacCulloch, The Reformation

events.title: Elizabethan Settlement Stabilizes the Church of England
events.description: Acts of Supremacy and Uniformity define a Protestant-but-broad national church under Elizabeth I.
events.details: Elizabeth I restored royal supremacy and mandated the Book of Common Prayer with moderate Protestant doctrine. The via media blended reformed theology with liturgical continuity, creating space for both evangelical and more traditional expressions within a single national church.
significance: Established a durable national church
Balanced reform with continuity
Shaped Anglican identity for centuries
sources: Acts of Supremacy and Uniformity (1559)
Patrick Collinson, The Elizabethan Puritan Movement
MacCulloch, The Reformation

events.title: Peace of Westphalia Ends the Thirty Years' War
events.description: Treaties end a devastating confessional war, expand toleration, and reshape European state sovereignty.
events.details: The Thirty Years' War ravaged central Europe, blending religious, dynastic, and territorial conflicts. The Peace of Westphalia confirmed territorial sovereignty, broadened toleration to include Calvinists, and weakened imperial and papal political influence, marking a shift toward modern statecraft and reducing religious wars in Europe.
significance: Expanded religious toleration
Rebalanced power among European states
Diminished papal temporal influence
sources: Treaties of Münster and Osnabrück (1648)
Geoffrey Parker, The Thirty Years' War
Justo Gonzalez, The Story of Christianity Vol. 2

figures.name: Martin Luther
figures.biography: German Augustinian whose critique of indulgences and emphasis on justification by faith sparked the Reformation. Translated the Bible into German, reshaping language and piety.
figures.significance: Central figure of early Protestantism; championed Scripture's primacy and salvation by grace through faith.
majorAchievements: Ninety-Five Theses
Diet of Worms stand
German Bible translation

figures.name: John Calvin
figures.biography: French reformer who systematized Reformed theology and built disciplined church structures in Geneva, influencing Protestantism globally.
figures.significance: Shaped Reformed tradition, church polity, and international networks of Protestant mission.
majorAchievements: Institutes of the Christian Religion
Geneva Ordinances
Training pastors for Europe

figures.name: Huldrych Zwingli
figures.biography: Swiss leader who advanced Scripture-centered reform in Zurich and advocated a symbolic understanding of the Lord's Supper.
figures.significance: Pioneered the Swiss Reformation and shaped non-Lutheran sacramental theology.
majorAchievements: Zurich reforms
Marburg Colloquy participation

figures.name: Thomas Cranmer
figures.biography: Architect of the English Reformation's liturgy; authored the Book of Common Prayer and shaped Anglican doctrine.
figures.significance: Defined Anglican worship and theology with enduring influence.
majorAchievements: Book of Common Prayer
Thirty-Nine Articles (foundational documents)
English liturgy

figures.name: Ignatius of Loyola
figures.biography: Spanish mystic who founded the Society of Jesus, emphasizing disciplined spirituality, education, and global mission in Catholic renewal.
figures.significance: Led Catholic renewal and global missions, countering Protestant expansion.
majorAchievements: Spiritual Exercises
Jesuit order
Global schools and missions
